facts.text: Robkar issued by the Ijlas-i-Khas Council of Regency, Patiala State, on February 6, 1919, levying royalty (Mehsul) at Rs. 50 per one lakh bricks from all kiln owners, irrespective of whether brick-kilns constructed on government land or not; if on government land, rent or damages in addition.
Notices of demand issued to appellants from Tehsil Office, Faridkot, on or about April 20, 1951.
Suit filed by appellants on May 13, 1952, in Court of Subordinate Judge, Faridkot, for declaration and injunction against the levy.
Trial Judge (Subordinate Judge, Faridkot) dismissed the suit.
On appeal to District Court, decision of trial Judge reversed.

Further appeal to High Court of Patiala and East Punjab States Union (PEPSU Punjab High Court) in Regular Second Appeal No. 29 of 1954; judgment and decree dated October 23, 1956, setting aside Additional District Judge's decision and restoring trial Judge's decision.
Appeal to Supreme Court with certificate under Art. 133(1)(c) of the Constitution.
Appellants concede claim confined to period after April 1, 1950; prior period saved by Art. 277; Finance Act, 1950, operates from April 1, 1950.
Authority of Regency Council to issue Robkar and its validity (unless affected by Indian law) not questioned.

legal_issues.text: Whether the levy of royalty at Rs. 50 per one lakh bricks under Robkar of February 6, 1919, continues to be effective after the enactment of the Finance Act, 1950.
Whether the Robkar is a law corresponding to the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944, so as to be repealed by s.13(2) of the Finance Act, 1950.

petitioner_arguments.text: Royalty under Robkar is in the nature of an excise duty, and Robkar is thus a law corresponding to the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944 (long title and preamble as consolidation and amending law)

petitioner_arguments.text: Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944, is comprehensive, providing levy on specified commodities and by implication exonerating others from excise duty.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sections 2(d), 3(1) and First Schedule of Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944

respondent_arguments.text: The Robkar imposes a royalty (Mehsul), not corresponding to the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944; only corresponding laws repealed by s.13(2) of Finance Act, 1950; non-corresponding laws saved by Art. 277.

court_reasoning.text: Section 13(2) of Finance Act, 1950, repeals only laws corresponding to Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944, extended by s.11; non-corresponding laws saved.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Finance Act, 1950, passed to give effect to financial proposals from April 1, 1950; s.11 extends Central Excises Act to Part B States.

court_reasoning.text: Robkar charges 'Mehsul Royalty' on bricks, not limited to scheduled excisable goods under Central Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944, confined to excisable goods in First Schedule (s.3(1), s.2(d)); no negative provision exonerating other goods.

court_reasoning.text: Act of 1944 consolidates prior 17 Acts on specific commodities; no intent to repeal non-specified local laws.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Robkar not a law corresponding to Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944; not repealed by s.13(2) Finance Act, 1950.

holdings.text: Robkar of 1919 imposing royalty on bricks is not a law corresponding to Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944, and not repealed by s.13(2) of Finance Act, 1950; levy remains valid.
Only laws corresponding to specified Indian statutes repealed under Finance Act, 1950; others saved.

statutes_cited.name: Finance Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Extended Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944, to Part B States; repealed corresponding State laws from April 1, 1950.

statutes_cited.name: Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944
statutes_cited.relevance: Levy of excise on specified excisable goods; defines scope limiting to scheduled items.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal; saves pre-Constitution levies.

outcome.summary: The appeal is dismissed, upholding the High Court's judgment restoring the trial court's dismissal of the suit; the Robkar levy remains valid post-Finance Act, 1950.

key_quotes.text: The only question in this appeal... is whether the levy of royalty at Rs. 50 per one lakh bricks under a Robkar issued... on February 6, 1919, is valid.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The provisions of s. 13(2) of the Finance Act, 1950, clearly show that only a law corresponding to the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944, was intended to be repealed.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The result, therefore, is quite clear that the Robkar... cannot be said to be a law corresponding to the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944, and is, therefore, not within the repeal created by s. 13(2) of the Finance Act, 1950.
key_quotes.speaker: court
